Description: The head and chest of a hollow terracotta lioness or panther, broken from a rhyton, with pouring-hole through the mouth. The head is turned to its right. There is slight damage to the ears. Two-piece mould. Very micaceous marl clay, mainly buff, but varying to orange: not certainly Egyptian.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Said to have been acquired in the Fayum: other objects marked with an alpha purchased from Chester were obtained in Alexandria. Hellenistic, second or first century BC. Comparanda: Near: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. E4677, perhaps from Naukratis, in Egyptian marl ware; Breccia 1930: no. 489, from the Hadra cemetery at Alexandria, both also parts of rhyta.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3738)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
